title: 115_hr1574
content: The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" is cited as the Act. It amends Title I of the Communications Act of 1934 to include viewpoint protection. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the revocation of licenses or other actions based on viewpoints expressed in broadcast content. The Commission is also restricted from imposing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews related to broadcast content. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews related to broadcast content, regardless of any affiliations or successors of the person seeking approval. This does not affect the Commission's authority to take action based on violations of specific laws. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews related to broadcast content. This does not affect the Commission's authority to take action based on violations of specific laws such as sections 1304, 1343, and 1464 of title 18, United States Code. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews related to broadcast content. It does not affect the Commission's authority to take action based on violations of specific laws such as sections 1304, 1343, and 1464 of title 18, United States Code, or conduct that would constitute a violation of such sections if disseminated through radio or television broadcast. Additionally, it includes violations or conduct that the Commission has the authority to regulate under section 312(a)(7). The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from placing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews related to broadcast content. It includes violations or conduct that the Commission has the authority to regulate under section 312(a)(7), 315, or 317 of this Act, as well as any public interest obligations of the broadcaster. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the President from directing agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their viewpoints expressed in broadcast content. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the President from directing agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their viewpoints expressed in broadcast content. The President is also restricted from directing agencies to impose conditions on approvals or decisions based on viewpoints. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the President from directing agencies to impose conditions on approvals or decisions based on viewpoints expressed in broadcast content. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the President from influencing agencies to base their decisions on specific viewpoints expressed in broadcast content. This does not limit the President's authority to direct agencies on other matters. The subsection clarifies that the President retains the authority to direct agencies to take action or impose conditions related to violations of specific laws, without influencing decisions based on broadcast content. The subsection clarifies that the President retains the authority to direct agencies to take action or impose conditions related to violations of specific laws, without influencing decisions based on broadcast content, including violations of sections 1304, 1343, and 1464 of title 18, United States Code. The subsection clarifies that the President retains the authority to direct agencies to take action related to violations of specific laws, including sections 1304, 1343, and 1464 of title 18, United States Code, through radio or television broadcast. The President can direct agencies to address violations of specific laws through radio or television broadcast, including incitement under the First Amendment, or to fulfill presidential duties under any law. The term "agency" is defined as in section 551 of the law. The President can direct agencies to address violations of specific laws through broadcast, including incitement under the First Amendment, or to fulfill presidential duties under any law. The term "agency" is defined as in section 551 of the law.
